lexUnit.name: scold.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: angrily remonstrate with or rebuke.

sentence.text: In all cases the ` boys " were given more freedom to explore whilst the ` girls " were kept close and scolded for being noisy and for ` tomboyish " behaviour !
She scolded incessantly but never beat her children .
The White House scolds Congress for being dilatory in finding cash for Panama and Nicaragua .
Scolding a child for being ` a bad boy " or ` a dirty girl " is not educative ; telling a child to do something ` because I say so " teaches her nothing useful .
She fled home on the underground , scolding herself for being such a coward , it could all be over now if she 'd been sensible .
She did n't even scold me for coming home to spy .
Then she scolded herself for getting carried away , when she should be preparing how best to approach her mother over the subject of Elaine .
He scolds me for leaving the flat .
Congress scolds the administration for not being forthcoming enough in its proposals for aid to Eastern Europe .
He scolds them for not disabling the car .
` You sound just like my old nurse , scolding me for not playing with my cousin whenever she stayed with us . "
Antoinette was being a pest , as usual , and Tante Héloise was scolding me for not wanting to play with her . ’
Renata Adler sat down at her typewriter at the New York Times and scolded Nicholson for a ` dreadfully written script " .
In the ensuing pandemonium the young musicians played on , but Matron came and took Anna away , scolding her gently for bad behaviour which would not be tolerated once she was settled in .
I remember it was he himself who put it most aptly one day when mother had scolded him for commencing work at home on a customer 's suit .
She felt a sharp pang at the thought that he could n't possibly desire her , and scolded herself for feeling like that .
It would have to be the chapel , Isabel decided , scolding herself for her cowardly hesitation .
She remembered that Aycliffe had brought up the matter of clothes , that Benedict himself had scolded her for her nip-cheese ways .
Coleen , however , although she loved Mr Cubbage , wanted time to think things over and would gently scold him for his haste .

The Pope 's Vicar of Rome , Cardinal Ugo Poletti , has taken to scolding the Christian Democrats for their divisions which may bring victory for the secular parties and the Communists in city elections on 29 October .
Tom himself was barely responsive to Faye 's mood , and when the artist scolded her brother about it , he only growled , ` I 'm tired .
Lavinia , still scolding , wiped the crumbs from their cardigans .

If a judge has slept badly , has had an indigestible breakfast , tripped over the cat , has been roundly abused by his wife and scolded by his children , or if his mind has been distracted by the children 's school reports , a narrow defeat at a curling match or whatever , he may be temporarily off form .
Because Joe and I were in the same position of being scolded by Mrs Joe , we were good friends , and Joe protected me from her anger whenever he could .
She had to be scolded .
RIGHT After jumping up , this dog is being scolded for his behaviour .
Now she looked almost like a child about to be scolded for some minor misdemeanour .
If they come , you 'll be scolded for not working . "
Four children were scolded on buses and smacked .
Mrs Diggory took refuge in scolding the dog and dragging him off the bed .
A nurse was scolding him and telling him to sit down and be quiet .
He so detested the word ` Enterprise " , with its ring of commerce , that at Poindexter 's trial he scolded the prosecutor every time he used it .
The adverts scold us and cajole us and wheedle us and fawn us to keep up with the Joneses .
Cecil King behaved liked a baron at the Daily Mirror in the 1960s , scolding the Wilson government and toying with the idea of political office .
I 'm just sorry she scolds you as well , Pip , and hits you with the stick .
